## Consumables and equipment

### Chemical reagents

- Hydrochloric acid, HCl (10 %), diluted from concentrated HCl (37 %).
- Redistilled water (MilliQ).

### Equipment

- Laboratory fume hood.
- Analytical balance (readability 0.1 mg).
- Laboratory furnace (max. 1100 °C).

### Other materials

- Porcelain crucibles.
- Desiccator with active desiccant.

## Preparation

### Sample preparation

- Freeze-dry wet sediment samples (see [Freeze Drying](freeze-drying.qmd) protocol).
- Grind dried sediment in an agate mortar.
- Sieve through a 100 µm mesh.

### Workspace preparation

- Clean all glassware with redistilled water (MilliQ).
- Verify that the fume hood is operational.

## Procedure

- Step-by-step instructions go here.

- Each step is a bullet point, written as a clear, imperative sentence.

- Weigh approximately **0.5 g** of homogenised sediment into a porcelain crucible.

:::{.callout-tip}
## Practical advice
Try to maintain similar sample masses across the batch. This improves comparability and simplifies calculations.
:::

- Programme the furnace to **550 °C** for **4 h**.

:::{.callout-important}
## Critical step
Do not open the furnace during the heating programme. Allow samples to cool in a desiccator to room temperature before weighing.
:::

- Record the mass in the laboratory form.

:::{.callout-note}
## Background
The mass loss at 550 °C corresponds to the combustion of organic matter. This is a widely used proxy, but see Heiri et al. (2001) for a discussion of its limitations.
:::

## Calculations

The organic matter content is calculated as:

$$
\text{LOI}_{550} = \frac{m_{105} - m_{550}}{m_{105}} \times 100
$$

where:

- $\text{LOI}_{550}$ — loss on ignition at 550 °C (%)
- $m_{105}$ — mass of sediment dried at 105 °C (g)
- $m_{550}$ — mass of sediment after ignition at 550 °C (g)
